docs.lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, when Ravinia Hayes-Cozier walked into a board meeting of AIDS Action, one of the country's largest AIDS umbrella organizations, she felt a familiar, sinking feeling. There was only one other African-American in the room. ''I was scared,'' acknowledged Ms. Hayes-Cozier, the executive director of the Harlem Directors Group, a coalition of service organizations for Upper Manhattan. She wondered if the two together would be able to corral support during policy discussions about the disease that had ravaged neighborhoods like hers since 1994.

headline.main: Shift in Money and Message As Minorities Take On AIDS

docs.abstract: Role of minorities in policy making and fund-raising to fight AIDS across country is growing, reflecting broad, fundamental shift; exec offices and boards of broad-based AIDS orgns look increasingly like AIDS Action, whose board is flush with black and Latino members; prominent black orgns like NAACP and tradtionally black churches have overcome their reluctance to take on issue, recognizing that AIDS in last decade has claimed more and more of their own; Latino groups have also become more involved; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several insurers have decided in recent weeks to pay for experimental treatments for cancer, but only for policyholders who participate in clinical trials sanctioned by federal health agencies. Until now, virtually all insurance companies routinely refused to pay for the care of patients in clinical research, contending that experimental drugs and procedures were not covered by their policies because they had not been deemed effective.

docs.lead_paragraph: A number of insurance companies have decided in recent weeks to pay for experimental treatments for cancer, but only for policyholders who participate in clinical trials sanctioned by Federal health agencies. Until now, virtually all insurance companies routinely refused to pay for the care of patients in clinical research. They argued that experimental drugs and procedures were not covered by their policies because they had not been deemed effective.

headline.main: Group of Insurers to Pay for Experimental Cancer Therapy

docs.abstract: Coalition of leading health insurers, including Oxford Health Plans, Cigna HealthCare, Aetna/US Healthcare and Prudential HealthCare, decided in recent weeks to pay for experimental treatments for cancer, but only for policyholders who participate in clinical trials sanctioned by Federal health agencies; until now, virtually all insurance companies routinely refused to pay for care of patients in clinical research; they argued that experimental drugs and procedures were not covered by their policies because they had not been deemed effective; insurance industry has begun to signal willingness to finance medical research, change that would have seemed improbable just few years ago; new programs are limited in scope, restricted to single state or adopted on test basis; most prominent effort is expected to be announced by New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman; insurers, members of New Jersey Association of Health Plans, include most health insurance companies in state, paying or administering benefits for 60 percent of New Jersey residents, or 4.8 million people (M)

byline.original: By GINA KOLATA and KURT EICHENWALD

docs.lead_paragraph: In a prelude to his cross-party appearance tomorrow with Senator John McCain to promote campaign finance reform, Bill Bradley spoke out yesterday against the influence of money in politics and attacked Vice President Al Gore as appearing to care more about ''preserving power'' than reducing the flow of campaign donations to Washington. ''After seven years in power, Al Gore has not come close to enacting campaign finance reform,'' Mr. Bradley said at Fordham University on Manhattan's West Side. ''I have profound differences with Al Gore. He is wedded to the ways of Washington. Not once has he called out for changes in the campaign finance system. It shows he doesn't care about reform as much as preserving power.''

headline.main: Bradley's Warm-Up Attacks Money in Politics

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidate Bill Bradley, in prelude to his cross-party appearance with Sen John McCain to promote campaign finance reform, speaks out at gathering at Fordham University in Manhattan against influence of money in politics and attacks Vice Pres Al Gore as appearing to care more about preserving power than in reducing flow of campaign donations to Washington (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The agreement struck this morning with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will give transit workers a 14.3 percent increase in wages and benefits over three years, union officials said, an increase that generally eclipses raises for public employees in the New York region in recent years. In typical fashion, the city transit workers began the negotiations by making a high-end demand of 9 percent annual wage increases, or a 27 percent total raise over a three-year contract. In equally typical fashion, the M.T.A., which runs the city's subways and buses, started out with a low-ball offer of less than 2.4 percent annual wage increases over four years. The average transit worker makes $39,000.

headline.main: At 14.3 Percent Over 3 Years Raise for Transit Workers Beats the Average
headline.kicker: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: THE BENCH MARKS

docs.abstract: Transport Workers Union leaders say agreement with Metropolitan Transportation Authority will give transit workers 14.3 percent increase in wages and benefits over three years, increase that generally eclipses raises for public employees in New York region in recent years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The coverage of the surgeon general's report on mental illness (front page, Dec. 13) cannot emphasize enough the shameful role that insurers play in the lack of care for patients with mental illness.

headline.main: A Step Forward on Mental Health

docs.abstract: Dr Elliot Wineburg letter holds coverage of Surgeon General's report on mental illness (Dec 13) cannot emphasize enough shameful role that insurers play in lack of care for patients with mental illness
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The coverage of the surgeon general's report on mental illness (front page, Dec. 13) cannot emphasize enough the shameful role that insurers play in the lack of care for patients with mental illness.

docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the surgeon general has put his imprimatur on the idea that one-fifth of America is in need of mental health care, we are in danger of seeing a burst of indiscriminate and misplaced new spending that could end up hurting, rather than helping, the people who need treatment most. When we first heard the 20 percent estimate for mental illness in the United States population, during the health-care debates of 1993 and 1994, it was easy to dismiss it as the claim of special interests -- psychiatrists, social workers and psychologists -- that would benefit from more spending. (And, predictably, Michael M. Faenza, the president of the National Mental Health Association, greeted Monday's 500-page report by Surgeon General David Satcher with the exultant remark, ''This is a historic day.'')

headline.main: Mentally Ill or Just Feeling Sad?

docs.abstract: Dr Sally L Satel Op-Ed article on assertion by Surgeon General David Satcher that one-fifth of America is in need of mental health care; warns against indiscriminate and misplaced new spending that could end up hurting rather than helping people who need treatment most; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Calling the nation's health care system ''too costly, too inaccessible and too bureaucratic,'' Senator John McCain today set out a plan of ''tailored reforms'' that included a federal program to help the low-income elderly pay for prescription drugs and a limited right to sue health maintenance organizations. Mr. McCain's plan, offered in a speech to the Charleston Rotary Club, was part of an effort to capitalize on his surge in New Hampshire by fleshing out his positions on issues. Health care -- and most particularly the soaring costs of prescription drugs -- has emerged as one of the hottest topics on the campaign trail this year, and until now it has been a policy arena largely dominated by the Democrats.

headline.main: McCain Unveils HealthPlan Calling for Modest Changes

docs.abstract: Republican presidential candidate Sen John McCain, in speech to Charleston Rotary Club in South Carolina, says nation's health care system is too costly, too inaccessible and too bureaucratic and sets out plan of 'tailored reforms' that includes federal program to help low-income elderly pay for prescription drugs and limited right to sue health maintenance organizations; highlights of plan discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's transit workers and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority drew close to a deal last night to avert a threatened strike, union officials said, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he expected that bus and subway service would be near normal today. ''There will be no strike tomorrow,'' Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference at 10:30 last night. ''The most that we'll have to deal with are work stoppages here and there.''

headline.main: TRANSIT UNION REPORTS PACT AVERTING A CITYWIDE STRIKE; MAYOR EXPECTS NORMAL DAY

docs.abstract: Officials of Transport Workers Union say union and Metropolitan Transportation Authority have reached contract agreement, averting threatened shutdown of New York City's bus and subway system; Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says there will be no strike, and that most city will be forced to deal with are sporadic work stoppages; praises union leaders after several days of harsh criticism; rank-and-file expresses relief, but also anger at Giuliani's handling of crisis; agreement reportedly calls for 14.3 percent increase in wages and benefits over three years, including pledge by management to make larger contributions to workers' pension plan; photos; maps (M)
